meanings.def: away from the inside of a place or thing
examples: She ran out into the corridor.
She shook the bag and some coins fell out.
out of something I got out of bed.
He opened the box and out jumped a frog.
Out you go! (= used to order somebody to leave a room)
(informal) He ran out the door.

meanings.def: away from or not at home or their place of work
examples: I called Liz but she was out.
Let's go out this evening (= for example to a restaurant or club).
We haven't had a night out for weeks.
out of something Mr Green is out of town this week.
I got an out of office reply to my email.

meanings.def: outside; not in a building
examples: It's cold out.
There were children playing out in the street.

meanings.def: used to show that something/somebody is removed from a place, job, etc.
examples: This detergent is good for getting stains out.
We want this government out.
out of something He got thrown out of the restaurant.

meanings.def: away from the edge of a place
examples: The boy dashed out into the road.
out of something Don't lean out of the window.

meanings.def: used to show where something comes from
examples: He drank his beer out of the bottle.
a romance straight out of a fairy tale
I paid for the damage out of my savings.
We'll get the truth out of her.

meanings.def: used to show what something is made from
examples: a statue made out of bronze

meanings.def: used to show that somebody/something does not have any of something
examples: We're out of milk.
He's been out of work for six months.
You're out of luck—she left ten minutes ago.

meanings.def: used to show that somebody/something is not or no longer in a particular state or condition
examples: Try and stay out of trouble.
I watched the car until it was out of sight.

meanings.def: used to show that somebody is no longer involved in something
examples: It was an awful job and I'm glad to be out of it.
He gets out of the army in a few weeks.
They'll be out (= of prison) on bail in no time.
Brown goes on to the semi-finals but Lee is out.

meanings.def: from a particular number or set
examples: You scored six out of ten.
Two out of three people think the President should resign.

meanings.def: clearly and loudly so that people can hear
examples: to call/cry/shout out
Read it out loud.
Nobody spoke out in his defence.

meanings.def: a long or a particular distance away from a place or from land
examples: She's working out in Australia.
He lives right out in the country.
The boats are all out at sea.
The ship sank ten miles out of Stockholm.

meanings.def: available to everyone; known to everyone
examples: When does her new book come out?
Word always gets out (= people find out about things) no matter how careful you are.
Out with it! (= say what you know)

meanings.def: used to show the reason why something is done
examples: I asked out of curiosity.
She did it out of spite.

meanings.def: not in the library; borrowed by somebody else
examples: The book you wanted is out on loan.

meanings.def: at or towards its lowest point on land
examples: I like walking on the wet sand when the tide is out.

meanings.def: if the sun, moon or stars are or come out, they can be seen from the earth and are not hidden by clouds
fully open
examples: There should be some snowdrops out by now.

meanings.def: if a team or team member is out, it is no longer their turn with the bat
examples: The West Indies were all out for 364 (= after scoring 364 runs in cricket).

meanings.def: if a player is out, they can no longer take part in the game
examples: If you have no more cards, you are out. The winner is the one with the most cards.

meanings.def: if the ball is out, it landed outside the line
examples: The umpire said the ball was out.
The ball landed out.

meanings.def: not correct or exact; wrong
examples: I was slightly out in my calculations.
Your guess was a long way out (= completely wrong).
The estimate was out by more than $100.

meanings.def: not possible or not allowed
examples: Swimming is out until the weather gets warmer.

meanings.def: not fashionable
examples: Black is out this year.

meanings.def: not or no longer burning or lit
examples: Suddenly all the lights went out.
The fire had burnt itself out.

meanings.def: at an end
examples: It was summer and school was out.
She was to regret her words before the day was out.

meanings.def: unconscious
examples: He was out for more than an hour and came round in the hospital.
She was knocked out cold.

meanings.def: on strike
examples: The dockers stayed out for several months.

meanings.def: to the end; completely
examples: Hear me out before you say anything.
We left them to fight it out (= settle a disagreement by fighting or arguing).

meanings.def: to be trying to get or do something
examples: I'm not out for revenge.
She's out for what she can get (= trying to get something for herself).
The company is out to capture the Canadian market.

meanings.def: going regularly to a place
examples: He was in and out of jail for most of his life.

meanings.def: able to go outside again after an illness
travelling around a place
examples: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.

meanings.def: going or leaving
examples: As soon as I get my money I'm out of here!

meanings.def: sad because you are not included in something
examples: We've only just moved here so we feel a little out of it.

meanings.def: not aware of what is happening, usually because of drinking too much alcohol, or taking drugs
examples: He looks completely out of it.

idioms.idiom: be out for something/to do something
idioms.def: to be trying to get or do something
examples: I'm not out for revenge.
She's out for what she can get (= trying to get something for herself).
The company is out to capture the Canadian market.
He was in and out of jail for most of his life.

idioms.def: able to go outside again after an illness
examples: We've been out and about talking to people all over the country.
As soon as I get my money I'm out of here!

idioms.def: sad because you are not included in something
examples: We've only just moved here so we feel a little out of it.
He looks completely out of it.

meanings.def: a way of avoiding having to do something
examples: She was desperately looking for an out.

meanings.def: all the details, especially the complicated or difficult ones
examples: the ins and outs of the problem
He quickly learned the ins and outs of the job.

idioms.def: all the details, especially the complicated or difficult ones
examples: the ins and outs of the problem
He quickly learned the ins and outs of the job.

meanings.def: having told other people that you are gay or lesbian
examples: an out gay man
I had been out since I was 17.

meanings.def: to say publicly that somebody is gay or lesbian, especially when they would prefer to keep this information private
examples: He is the latest politician to be outed by the media.

meanings.def: to say something publicly about somebody/something that they would prefer to keep secret
examples: The man who claimed to have found the diaries has been outed as a fraud.
Their motives were outed as purely financial.

meanings.def: greater, better, further, longer, etc.
examples: outnumber
outwit
outgrow
outlive

meanings.def: outside; outward; away from
examples: outbuildings
outpatient
outlying
outgoing
